Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: Strong tests of life history theory using experimental reduction of embryo energy content in diverse marine invertebrates
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biologists studying the evolution of life history strategies examine trade-offs between traits to understand how natural selection acts to maximize reproductive success. One fundamental trade-off occurs between the size and number of offspring: an organism can produce many small offspring, or just a few large offspring. There is a large body of theory explaining how these strategies affect reproductive success, but in animals, tests of this theory have been done in only two groups: vertebrates and sea urchins. The proposed research uses experimental embryological techniques to test theory in a much more diverse suite of animals, including members of two of the three major lineages of bilaterally symmetric animals: deuterostomes (hemichordates and echinoderms) and lophotrochozoans (annelids, flatworms, and molluscs).

The proposed work integrates research and education at two institutions focused on providing meaningful student research experiences. The grant will support the development of a series of web-based lesson plans that will be made available for adoption by any institution of higher learning. These lesson plans will be developed through a series of pilot programs run during introductory and upper level biology classes at both institutions. The grant will provide direct support for 8-10 undergraduates and one graduate student, while lesson plans will provide in-class research opportunities for hundreds of additional students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among animal species, there is huge variation in how much energy parents invest in each of their offspring. To understand how this “per-offspring investment” evolves, it is necessary to understand how it affects the likelihood that offspring will survive. Marine invertebrates are excellent systems in which to study this relationship because in many species the only parental investment is the energy placed in the egg, and because in some species biologists can manipulate egg (or embryo) energy content and thus directly test its effects on offspring survival.

In this study we aimed to answer two questions about how per-offspring investment is related to offspring fitness: 1) how does egg energy content affect the amount of time that offspring spend in larval stages, and 2) how does egg energy content affect the size and growth rate of juveniles? We sought to answer these questions experimentally using a relatively novel method: ablating one or a few specific energy-rich cells in early embryos using a microscope-mounted laser, then comparing developmental timing and juvenile size and growth rate between these reduced-energy embryos and unmanipulated embryos. This method, we hoped, would allow us to carry out these experiments in members of a large group of animals – spiralians, including flatworms, segmented worms, and molluscs – where embryo energy content had previously been manipulated only very rarely.

Unfortunately, though we were able to use the laser to ablate target cells in a number of species, we were not able to rear embryos through development so did not achieve our original goals. However, we did make observations that addressed a number of related questions. One such project concerned the relationship of egg size (which is closely related to energy content) with early embryonic development. We carried out a broad comparative analysis that demonstrated that spiralians with larger eggs allocate more embryonic cytoplasm to cells that are fated to form the juvenile midgut, a finding that has implications for how feeding and nonfeeding larval development evolve in this large group of marine invertebrates. Other projects focused on the relationship between egg size and energy content in a marine snail; the effects of habitat choice on fecundity in another marine snail; the development of a seastar; and the effects of food abundance on the form of developing seastar larvae.

During this project, three graduate students and nine undergraduates were trained in experimental design, analysis, and presentation of results, as well as many methods (e.g., larval culture, flow cytometry, microscopy). Students involved in the project gave ten presentations on their work at five scientific conferences, with two student poster presentations winning in “best student presentation” competitions at these conferences. Additional conference presentations will occur in the next two years. The project has so far yielded five publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals, and we expect to publish at least three more manuscripts based on grant-supported work in the next 1-2 years.
